elements.content: Triazacyclononane (TACN) was coupled to glycine (LGly), alanine (LAla), and phenylalanine (LPhe) via standard solution phase peptide coupling techniques. Copper(II) complexes of these new ligand−amino acid conjugates, [(CuLGly)2](ClO4)4 (1), [(CuLAla)2Cl](ClO4)3 (2), and [Cu2LPheCl4] (3), were synthesized and characterized. The X-ray crystal structures of 2 and 3 were determined. Complex 2 is a dimeric species where LAla bridges between copper ions via its two TACN amine nitrogen atoms to one copper while the Ala terminal amine and carbonyl oxygen bind to the other copper. Complex 3 is bimetallic but only contains one LPhe ligand that bridges between the copper ions.
elements.clean_text: Triazacyclononane (TACN) was coupled to glycine (LGly), alanine (LAla), and phenylalanine (LPhe) via standard solution phase peptide coupling techniques. Copper(II) complexes of these new ligand-amino acid conjugates, [(CuLGly)2](ClO4)4 (1), [(CuLAla)2Cl](ClO4)3 (2), and [Cu2LPheCl4] (3), were synthesized and characterized. The X-ray crystal structures of 2 and 3 were determined. Complex 2 is a dimeric species where LAla bridges between copper ions via its two TACN amine nitrogen atoms to one copper while the Ala terminal amine and carbonyl oxygen bind to the other copper. Complex 3 is bimetallic but only contains one LPhe ligand that bridges between the copper ions.

elements.content: A new family of ligand−amino acid conjugates was synthesized by coupling TACN to glycine (LGly), alanine (LAla), or phenylalanine (LPhe) using standard peptide coupling techniques. Copper(II) complexes were synthesized with these ligands.
elements.clean_text: A new family of ligand-amino acid conjugates was synthesized by coupling TACN to glycine (LGly), alanine (LAla), or phenylalanine (LPhe) using standard peptide coupling techniques. Copper(II) complexes were synthesized with these ligands.

elements.content: Coordination chemistry in metalloproteins is dominated by amino acids since amino acid side chains and backbone heteroatoms entail the majority of ligands available to coordinate to metal ions. Small molecule models of metal sites in metalloproteins are an integral part of bioinorganic chemistry, and the design of new ligands to model challenging structural and/or functional motifs plays an important role in the development of new model complexes. Most model complexes use non-amino-acid ligands that mimic various aspects of the ligand environment found in the protein. Our laboratory is developing a new class of ligand−peptide conjugates where small peptides are coupled to “standard” ligands. Here we report our initial successes in coupling the tridentate ligand 1,4,7-triazacyclononane (TACN) with amino acids to form ligand−amino acid conjugates. The synthesis and characterization of copper(II) complexes of these new ligands are also reported.
elements.clean_text: Coordination chemistry in metalloproteins is dominated by amino acids since amino acid side chains and backbone heteroatoms entail the majority of ligands available to coordinate to metal ions. Small molecule models of metal sites in metalloproteins are an integral part of bioinorganic chemistry, and the design of new ligands to model challenging structural and/or functional motifs plays an important role in the development of new model complexes. Most model complexes use non-amino-acid ligands that mimic various aspects of the ligand environment found in the protein. Our laboratory is developing a new class of ligand-peptide conjugates where small peptides are coupled to "standard" ligands. Here we report our initial successes in coupling the tridentate ligand 1,4,7-triazacyclononane (TACN) with amino acids to form ligand-amino acid conjugates. The synthesis and characterization of copper(II) complexes of these new ligands are also reported.

elements.content: Syntheses of Ligands LGly, LAla, and LPhe and Complexes 1−3
elements.clean_text: 1  Syntheses of Ligands LGly, LAla, and LPhe and Complexes 1-3

elements.content: Our general synthetic approach for creating ligand−peptide conjugates relies on coupling functionalized ligands to the O-terminus of Boc-protected amino acids or oligopeptides (Boc = N-tert-butoxycarbonyl). The ligand−peptide conjugate can then be deprotected and purified. Ligands LGly, LAla, and LPhe were synthesized according to Scheme by coupling the secondary amine nitrogen of Boc2TACN to the acid group of Boc-protected amino acids glycine (Gly), alanine (Ala), or phenylalanine (Phe), respectively.
elements.clean_text: Our general synthetic approach for creating ligand-peptide conjugates relies on coupling functionalized ligands to the O-terminus of Boc-protected amino acids or oligopeptides (Boc = N-tert-butoxycarbonyl). The ligand-peptide conjugate can then be deprotected and purified. Ligands LGly, LAla, and LPhe were synthesized according to Scheme  by coupling the secondary amine nitrogen of Boc2TACN to the acid group of Boc-protected amino acids glycine (Gly), alanine (Ala), or phenylalanine (Phe), respectively.

elements.content: Because of our interest in copper-containing metalloproteins, we set off to synthesize copper complexes of ligands LGly, LAla, and LPhe to explore the coordination chemistry of these new ligand−amino acid conjugates. Copper complexes [(CuLGly)2](ClO4)4 (1), [(CuLAla)2Cl](ClO4)3 (2), and [Cu2LPheCl4] (3) were synthesized in methanol by combining the ligand with a copper(II) salt. Cupric perchlorate hexahydrate was used to synthesize 1 and 2, whereas cupric chloride was used to synthesize 3. Complexes 1 and 2 are dimeric with a 2:2 ligand−metal stoichiometry. The dimeric formulation for 1 and 2 was determined in solution by ESI-MS. For 1 in CH3CN:  m/z = 797 [M − ClO4]+, m/z = 348 [M − CuLGly(ClO4)3]+. For 2 in CH3CN:  m/z = 825 [M − Cl]+, m/z = 761 [M − ClO4]+, m/z = 362 [M − CuLAlaCl(ClO4)2]+. The dimeric form of 2 was verified in the solid state by X-ray crystallography.
elements.clean_text: Because of our interest in copper-containing metalloproteins, we set off to synthesize copper complexes of ligands LGly, LAla, and LPhe to explore the coordination chemistry of these new ligand-amino acid conjugates. Copper complexes [(CuLGly)2](ClO4)4 (1), [(CuLAla)2Cl](ClO4)3 (2), and [Cu2LPheCl4] (3) were synthesized in methanol by combining the ligand with a copper(II) salt. Cupric perchlorate hexahydrate was used to synthesize 1 and 2, whereas cupric chloride was used to synthesize 3. Complexes 1 and 2 are dimeric with a 2:2 ligand-metal stoichiometry. The dimeric formulation for  1 and 2 was determined in solution by ESI-MS. For 1 in CH3CN: m/z = 797 [M - ClO4]+, m/z = 348 [M - CuLGly(ClO4)3]+. For 2 in CH3CN: m/z = 825 [M - Cl]+, m/z = 761 [M - ClO4]+, m/z = 362 [M - CuLAlaCl(ClO4)2]+. The dimeric form of 2 was verified in the solid state by X-ray crystallography.

elements.content: The crystal structure of 2 confirmed that it is composed of bimetallic species where two copper(II) ions are bridged via two LAla ligands to form a 4+ cation (Figure ). The charge is balanced by one bridging chloride anion and three outer sphere perchlorate anions. The chloride links molecules of 2 in the crystal lattice by bridging between Cu1 from one dimer and Cu2 from an adjacent dimer.
elements.clean_text: The crystal structure of 2 confirmed that it is composed of bimetallic species where two copper(II) ions are bridged via two LAla ligands to form a 4+ cation (Figure ). The charge is balanced by one bridging chloride anion and three outer sphere perchlorate anions. The chloride links molecules of 2 in the crystal lattice by bridging between Cu1 from one dimer and Cu2 from an adjacent dimer.

elements.content: Representation of the X-ray structure of2 as 50% thermal ellipsoids. H atoms have been omitted for clarity. Selected bond distances (Å):  Cu1−O2, 1.998(3); Cu1−N2, 1.999(3); Cu1−N1, 2.031(3); Cu1−N8, 2.057(3); Cu1−Cl1, 2.508(1); Cu2−N6, 1.984(3); Cu1−O1, 1.999(3); Cu2−N4, 2.007(3); Cu2−N5, 2.025(3); Cu2−Cl1A, 2.526(1).
elements.clean_text: 1  Representation of the X-ray structure of2 as 50% thermal ellipsoids. H atoms have been omitted for clarity. Selected bond distances (Å): Cu1-O2, 1.998(3); Cu1-N2, 1.999(3); Cu1-N1, 2.031(3); Cu1-N8, 2.057(3); Cu1-Cl1, 2.508(1); Cu2-N6, 1.984(3); Cu1-O1, 1.999(3); Cu2-N4, 2.007(3); Cu2-N5, 2.025(3); Cu2-Cl1A, 2.526(1).

elements.content: The TACN portion of the LAla ligand binds to Cu1 via two amine nitrogens, but the amide nitrogen is not coordinated. The Cu1···N3 distance of 2.96 Å in 2 stands in contrast to the rare examples of copper complexes with coordinated tertiary amides (2.16−2.49 Å). These amide-coordinated species are sensitive to C−N bond cleavage, while 2 is stable in methanol. The stability of the amide C−N bonds in 2 can be attested to the fact that the metal is not coordinated by the amide N atom. The Ala portion of the same ligand coordinates to the other copper atom in 2, Cu2, via the terminal amine nitrogen and the carbonyl oxygen atom. The second ligand in the bimetallic complex is related via a noncrystallographic pseudo-C 2 axis to the first ligand; thus, two LAla ligands bridge between the copper atoms in 2.
elements.clean_text: The TACN portion of the LAla ligand binds to Cu1 via two amine nitrogens, but the amide nitrogen is not coordinated. The Cu1⋅⋅⋅N3 distance of 2.96 Å in 2 stands in contrast to the rare examples of copper complexes with coordinated tertiary amides (2.16-2.49 Å). These amide-coordinated species are sensitive to C-N bond cleavage, while 2 is stable in methanol. The stability of the amide C-N bonds in 2 can be attested to the fact that the metal is not coordinated by the amide N atom. The Ala portion of the same ligand coordinates to the other copper atom in 2, Cu2, via the terminal amine nitrogen and the carbonyl oxygen atom. The second ligand in the bimetallic complex is related via a noncrystallographic pseudo-C 2 axis to the first ligand; thus, two LAla ligands bridge between the copper atoms in 2.

elements.content: The coordination geometry around each copper is closest to square pyramidal, with a N3O ligand set in the equatorial plane and a chloride ligand in the axial position (τ = 0.16 and 0.10 for Cu1 and Cu2, respectively). The chloride anions bridge between bimetallic moieties [∠Cu−Cl−Cu = 158.25(5)°] to create linear chains of molecules along the crystallographic b axis (see Figure S5). The intra- and intermolecular Cu···Cu distances in 2 are long (> 4.9 Å), making any significant magnetic coupling between copper(II) ions unlikely, an assertion corroborated by the typical axial EPR spectrum of 2 (g ⊥ = 2.08, g ∥ = 2.39, A Cu ∥ = 120 G).
elements.clean_text: The coordination geometry around each copper is closest to square pyramidal, with a N3O ligand set in the equatorial plane and a chloride ligand in the axial position (τ = 0.16 and 0.10 for Cu1 and Cu2, respectively). The chloride anions bridge between bimetallic moieties [∠Cu-Cl-Cu = 158.25(5)°] to create linear chains of molecules along the crystallographic b axis (see Figure S5). The intra- and intermolecular Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances in 2 are long (> 4.9 Å), making any significant magnetic coupling between copper(II) ions unlikely, an assertion corroborated by the typical axial EPR spectrum of 2 (g ⊥ = 2.08, g ∥ = 2.39, A Cu ∥ = 120 G).

elements.content: Unlike the dimeric 2:2 ligand−metal ratio of 1 and 2, in the solid state 3 has a 1:2 ligand−metal stoichiometry (vide infra). Attempts to synthesize the 1:1 or 2:2 ligand−copper complex using LPhe were unsuccessful, with exclusive formation of 3 even when excess LPhe was used. Attempts to synthesize copper complexes with LPhe using cupric perchlorate were also unsuccessful. The inability of LPhe to form symmetrical dimers with Cu(ClO4)2, as LGly and LAla do in 1 and 2, may be a consequence of steric interactions of the bulkier Phe side chains.
elements.clean_text: Unlike the dimeric 2:2 ligand-metal ratio of 1 and 2, in the solid state 3 has a 1:2 ligand-metal stoichiometry (vide infra). Attempts to synthesize the 1:1 or 2:2 ligand-copper complex using LPhe were unsuccessful, with exclusive formation of 3 even when excess LPhe was used. Attempts to synthesize copper complexes with LPhe using cupric perchlorate were also unsuccessful. The inability of LPhe to form symmetrical dimers with Cu(ClO4)2, as LGly and LAla do in 1 and 2, may be a consequence of steric interactions of the bulkier Phe side chains.

elements.content: The crystal structure of 3 revealed a bimetallic complex that is different than 2 (Figure ). Here, LPhe bridges between the two copper(II) ions in a manner similar to 2 with the TACN ring binding to Cu1 through the amine N atoms in a bidentate fashion and the Phe portion of the ligand binding to Cu2 through the terminal amine and the carbonyl O atom. However, unlike the symmetric binding mode in 2, the coordination sphere around each copper(II) ion in 3 is completed by two chloride ligands.
elements.clean_text: The crystal structure of 3 revealed a bimetallic complex that is different than 2 (Figure ). Here, LPhe bridges between the two copper(II) ions in a manner similar to 2 with the TACN ring binding to Cu1 through the amine N atoms in a bidentate fashion and the Phe portion of the ligand binding to Cu2 through the terminal amine and the carbonyl O atom. However, unlike the symmetric binding mode in 2, the coordination sphere around each copper(II) ion in 3 is completed by two chloride ligands.

elements.content: Representation of the X-ray crystal structure of3 as 50% thermal ellipsoids. H atoms have been omitted for clarity. Selected bond distances (Å):  Cu1−N1, 2.039(2); Cu1−N2, 2.032(2); Cu1−Cl1, 2.2729(8); Cu1−Cl2, 2.2852(8); Cu1···N3, 2.783(2); Cu2−O1, 2.007(2); Cu2−N4, 2.004(2); Cu2−Cl3, 2.2500(8); Cu2−Cl4, 2.2392(7); Cu2···Cl1, 3.042(1).
elements.clean_text: 2  Representation of the X-ray crystal structure of3 as 50% thermal ellipsoids. H atoms have been omitted for clarity. Selected bond distances (Å): Cu1-N1, 2.039(2); Cu1-N2, 2.032(2); Cu1-Cl1, 2.2729(8); Cu1-Cl2, 2.2852(8); Cu1⋅⋅⋅N3, 2.783(2); Cu2-O1, 2.007(2); Cu2-N4, 2.004(2); Cu2-Cl3, 2.2500(8); Cu2-Cl4, 2.2392(7); Cu2⋅⋅⋅Cl1, 3.042(1).

elements.content: The coordination geometry around both copper(II) ions is square planar, with an N2Cl2 ligand set around Cu1 and a NOCl2 ligand set around Cu2. However, if axial interactions are considered, the geometry is closer to elongated octahedral. The axial distances involving Cu1 are shorter than the sum of their van der Waals radii [Cu1···N3 = 2.783(2) Å, intramolecular; Cu1A···Cl3 = 2.818(1) Å, intermolecular], suggesting weak Cu···ligand interactions. Likewise, the axial distances involving Cu2 are also shorter than the sum of their van der Waals radii [Cu2···Cl1 = 3.042(1) Å, intramolecular; Cu2···Cl2A = 3.087(1) Å, intermolecular]. The bimetallic complexes, loosely linked through weak intra- and intermolecular axial bonds, consequently form chains along the crystallographic b axis (see Figure S7).
elements.clean_text: The coordination geometry around both copper(II) ions is square planar, with an N2Cl2 ligand set around Cu1 and  a NOCl2 ligand set around Cu2. However, if axial interactions are considered, the geometry is closer to elongated octahedral. The axial distances involving Cu1 are shorter than the sum of their van der Waals radii [Cu1⋅⋅⋅N3 = 2.783(2) Å, intramolecular; Cu1A⋅⋅⋅Cl3 = 2.818(1) Å, intermolecular], suggesting weak Cu⋅⋅⋅ligand interactions. Likewise, the axial distances involving Cu2 are also shorter than the sum of their van der Waals radii [Cu2⋅⋅⋅Cl1 = 3.042(1) Å, intramolecular; Cu2⋅⋅⋅Cl2A = 3.087(1) Å, intermolecular]. The bimetallic complexes, loosely linked through weak intra- and intermolecular axial bonds, consequently form chains along the crystallographic b axis (see Figure S7).

elements.content: Evidence of the two distinct copper coordination environments for 3 in solution was provided by EPR spectroscopy. The EPR spectrum of a frozen solution of 3 clearly indicates two different copper environments based on two distinct g ∥ signals (Cu1, g ∥ = 2.41, A Cu ∥ = 119 G; Cu2, g ∥ = 2.24, A Cu ∥ = 177 G). Whether 3 retains its bimetallic structure or dissociates is difficult to ascertain from EPR alone. However, no evidence of the bimetallic species was observed by mass spectroscopy (ESI-MS for 3 in H2O:  m/z = 410 [M − CuCl2]+, m/z = 374 [M − CuCl3]+), suggesting that in solution 3 dissociates into 1:1 LPheCu monomers and solvated Cu2+.
elements.clean_text: Evidence of the two distinct copper coordination environments for 3 in solution was provided by EPR spectroscopy. The EPR spectrum of a frozen solution of 3 clearly indicates two different copper environments based on two distinct g ∥ signals (Cu1, g ∥ = 2.41, A Cu ∥ = 119 G; Cu2, g ∥ = 2.24, A Cu ∥ = 177 G). Whether 3 retains its bimetallic structure or dissociates is difficult to ascertain from EPR alone. However, no evidence of the bimetallic species was observed by mass spectroscopy (ESI-MS for 3 in H2O: m/z = 410 [M - CuCl2]+, m/z = 374 [M - CuCl3]+), suggesting that in solution 3 dissociates into 1:1 LPheCu monomers and solvated Cu2+.

elements.content: In summary, we have synthesized a new family of ligand−amino acid conjugates by coupling TACN to glycine, alanine, and phenylalanine. The copper(II) complexes of these ligands have been synthesized and characterized. The ligands coordinate in a bridging mode between copper ions. The TACN amines coordinate to one copper ion whereas the amino acid amine and carbonyl oxygen coordinate to the other copper ion.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have synthesized a new family of ligand-amino acid conjugates by coupling TACN to glycine, alanine, and phenylalanine. The copper(II) complexes of these ligands have been synthesized and characterized. The ligands coordinate in a bridging mode between copper ions. The TACN amines coordinate to one copper ion whereas the amino acid amine and carbonyl oxygen coordinate to the other copper ion.

metadata.title: TACN−Amino Acid Conjugates and Their Copper(II) Complexes
